Award.AwardTitle: Chiroptical Spectroscopic Studies on Supramolecular Aggregates
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Prasad Polavarapu at Vanderbilt University to study "chiral" molecules - that is, molecules with handedness associated with them. Differences in pharmacological activity between a left-handed chiral molecule and its right-handed mirror image make it necessary to isolate these molecules from one another to investigate their properties. Dr. Polavarapu's group specifically studies chiral surfactant molecules which form special aggregate structures with encapsulation properties (used, for example, for drug delivery). They seek improved understanding of the properties of these molecules to enable better control and use. Involvement of students from both Vanderbilt and Tennessee State University through collaboration with Dr. Nsoki Phambu, is expected to provide valuable research training opportunities for undergraduates interested in the STEM disciplines.

The work focuses on chiral aggregates based on tartaric acid chemical templates. Recently developed vibrational circular dichroism (VCD) is used to probe the aggregates, along with established electronic circular dichroism (ECD) and optical rotatory dispersion (ORD). Three-dimensional molecular structures of chiral aggregates are determined with these tools and additional data from methods such as electron microscopy and atomic force microscopy. Molecular dynamics simulations provide further understanding of possible structures. Quantum chemical predictions of chiroptical spectroscopic properties and comparison to corresponding experimental observations are used to further unravel the relation between chiral aggregates and their spectroscopic properties. These studies are expected to help establish the relationship between the structures of chiral aggregates and their chiroptical properties. This work is is also expected to better define the analytical capabilities of chiroptical spectroscopic methods for characterizing chiral aggregates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF grant (CHE1464874) has helped advance the field of chiroptical spectroscopy for applications to supramolecular aggregates formed by chiral surfactants, as well as to chiral natural products and chiral organic molecules. Chiroptical spectroscopy methods included vibrational Raman optical activity, vibrational circular dichroism and electronic circular dichroism and specific optical rotation.  A tartaric acid based anionic liquid surfactant, synthesized and analyzed using chiroptical spectroscopic methods, was found to form micelles and reverse micelles at room temperature. These results led to securing a US patent (No. 10,526,273). Several other tartaric acid based amphiphiles that form supramolecular aggregates were also synthesized and analyzed. Specific optical rotation, in particular, was found to be a versatile technique for the identification of critical micelle concentration and micellar growth of aggregates formed by tartaric acid based amphiphiles. For analyzing the chiroptical spectroscopic data, a computer program, CDSpecTech, was developed and made freely available. These developments in chiroptical spectroscopy helped determine the absolute configurations of several organic compounds, including agathisflavone, axially chiral sulfonate, inuloxin C, crispine analogs, natural product-derived chiral pyrrolidine-2,5-diones, alpha-amino acids with N-substitution, t-butylphenylphosphinoamidate, and naturally occurring [5]-and [3]-Ladderanoic acids. Intermolecular hydrogen bonding Interactions in methanol solvent were found not to limit the applications of chiroptical spectroscopy for chiral structural elucidations. Vibrational Raman optical activity and vibrational circular dichroism spectroscopies have also been ascertained to help prevent arriving at incorrect chemical structures of chiral compounds.  This grant funding has led to 27 peer reviewed research publications, one book on Chiroptical Spectroscopy: Fundamentals and Applications, and one edited book on Chiral Analysis. In addition, this funding has helped provide professional training for graduate students and post-doctoral fellows, which is critical for advancing the future research and educational opportunities.
